Award.AwardTitle: 2014 Cellular and Molecular Bioengineering (CMBE) Conference, January 7-11, 2014, La Jolla, California.

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Mechanical forces and mechanical perturbations have ubiquitous roles in biological systems over different length scales, from molecular to subcellular to cellular to organismal levels. The problems in this area are of interdisciplinary nature, spanning engineering and biology. Understanding the effect of mechanical inputs to biological systems has significant ramifications in several areas of biomedical science and engineering, including, but not limited to, cell biology, cellular and tissue engineering, and regenerative medicine. The 2014 Cellular and Molecular Bioengineering (CMBE) Conference will catalyze developments in this field by bringing together leading academics with interests in experimental and theoretical aspects of multi-scale mechanobiology, and by enabling and encouraging the exchange of ideas and interactions among young and established investigators and among scientists with complementary interests and expertise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CBET-1358349; Conference Support: 2014 Cellular and Molecular Bioengineering (CMBE) Conference, Hilton Torrey Pines, La Jolla, CA, January 7-11th, 2014

The major goal of this project was to provide funding for students, trainees, young faculty, and invited speakers to attend and present work at the 2014 BMES Cell and Molecular Bioengineering Conference.  

The specific theme of the 2014 conference was ‘Multi-scale Mechanobiology: From Morphogenesis to Nuclear Mechanotransduction’. Our expanding understanding of the role that mechanical perturbations play in every aspect of life, from morphogenesis to chromatin remodeling, motivated the mission of this conference. We planned a conference integrating both engineers and biologists to encourage sharing of ideas toward these common goals, and the conference addressed the key problem of understanding how mechanical perturbations translate to changes in cellular activity, from the organismal to nuclear level. 

Intellectual Merit: This conference fulfilled its mission of executing the second ever CMBE Conference, and presented a 4-day conference with sessions focused on the theme of Multi-Scale Mechanobiology.  This meeting brought together the best thinkers in the field of CMBE to discuss these topics, and fostered much discussion and debate.  This funding also allowed for 19 trainees and/or young investigators to attend the meeting through travel awards and rising star designations.  

Broader Impacts: This conference drew in 140 attendees (up from 120 in 2014), including 11 funded students/postdocs, 8 Rising Stars, and 5 Keynote Speakers.   Importantly, ~70% were first time attendees, and 76% were BMES members, demonstrating the important role that BMES is playing supporting attendance at this conference.  Furthermore, 92% of attendees indicated that their expectations had been met and 96% said that that they would recommend the CMBE meeting to colleagues. The awarded NSF funds were used to support travel awards for the 8 Rising Star investigators and 11 students and trainees as well as 2 of the Keynote speakers. 

Graduate students/postdoctoral fellows who were selected by the organizing committee to receive Student/Fellow Awards presented short talks that were integrated into the general sessions. In addition, the junior independent investigators who were selected as ‘Rising Stars’ presented their work during a special session that took place on the first day of the meeting in order to showcase their work. The Rising Star session was followed by a ‘Lunches with Leaders’ where recipients of both award types had an informal lunch established invited speakers.
